data.text: Selle Anatomica. Works for me and I'm a chunky monkey. Perfect from Day 1. No pain.
data.author: Gabi Gee

data.text: Do not buy a soft squishy gel saddle. The Selle leather saddle is a great one. Lots of great saddles. No Gel or gel pad on top. Trust me
data.author: Erik Pipins

data.text: I would stay away from the big wide cushy saddle, they put you in a weird position and will cause hip pain if riding long distance. I like the fizik saddles. I suggest wearing padded shorts and go with a suspension seat post to absorb some of the bumps
data.author: Jason Heinrich

data.text: I suspect a wide one that is a soft gel top is what you expect, .. If you plan on riding a lot as part of a plan to exercise weight off then the hard for now leather saddles others suggest could be part of the plan..
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: Saddle height and position has as much to do with comfort as the saddle it's self ... most of a persons weight should be on their legs like when one walks and runs. Have a bike shop fit your saddle height to you.
data.author: Harry Fortney

data.text: Another in the infinite number of 'which saddle should I buy' questions ..
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: Many bike stores will allow you to purchase a bike saddle, try it for a few rides and then return it within a specified time as long as you have the original packaging and the saddle is undamaged. Some shops will give you a refund while others will let you exchange it for a different model which you can then try. It is a good way of trying a few saddles to see which will suit you best as it will often take several rides before you know if it is comfortable for you. Ask your local bike shop about their policy. Also....don't forget to try padded bike shorts.
data.author: David Cavers

data.text: üò≥üò≥üò≥ü§îü•∞
data.author: Mickey L. Foster

data.text: It seems counter-intuitive but I've found that the unpadded saddles are more comfortable than the squishy heavily padded gel ones. A little padding is ok but don't get totally turned off by the firmer saddles. I think the firmer saddles provide better support for your sit bones while the soft ones allow for too much movement so your butt kinda goes all over too much.
data.author: Martin Lim

data.text: yeah I agree, it's easy to think you need a really soft squishy seat for comfort but over time that becomes less comfortable
data.author: Sarah Vickers

data.text: Your pelvic bones develop callouses, so harder saddles are actually more comfortable once your bones adapt (which doesn't take long).
data.author: Nora Somer

data.text: I honestly don't care if its soft or firm. I am trying to find a good bike seat that is not going to cause brushes all over my but and legs every time I ride.
data.author: Angel L Daugherty

data.text: I don't know about a seat leaving bruises on your body; reckon that would be very painful and uncomfortable before it even happens. So one of the key points about comfort is to determine the size of the saddle you need. Several people have mentioned how to do that. Even if you can't conveniently sample saddles, just getting the sizing right is a big step.
data.author: Martin Lim

data.text: Stay away from soft saddles! They grab the fleshy bits between your legs and chafe. Get a firm saddle that lets you glide around on it. I have a Brooks B17 and I love it. After having a succession of softer saddles, some with gel, some without, some with perineal cutouts, some without, I have to say the Brooks is the most comfortable saddle out of the bunch. It's so comfy I don't wear padded chamois anymore, just street clothes!
data.author: David J. Syrotiak

data.text: Have your sit bones measured to ensure your seat is wide enough to support your hips and knees - and then as others have said get a firm seat in the right width.
data.author: Victoria James

data.text: where and how do I do that?
data.author: Angel L Daugherty

data.text: You should be able to do that at any good bike shop, they usually offer fittings. Otherwise a piece of cardboard, some chalk, and a YouTube video about how to measure sit bones!
data.author: Victoria James

data.text: 10,000kms of pedalling.
data.author: Paul Hamon

data.text: As an over weight woman, I'd suggest finding a store that will let you try out different saddles. I also love my big wide cushy saddle and every skinny man who tells me it's wrong isn't me and isn't built like me. Everybody's different, that's why you should just experiment and figure out what works for you. Start with types (skinny/hard vs. big/cushy) then refine.
data.author: Alison Clark

data.author: Julie Hallam

data.text: You mention a delicate aspect of biking. For short rides up to 15 km, you you probably won‚Äôt feel a lot of difference. My mom, who still does rides up to 100km at age 75, and knows here gear, bought a new bike. Her own saddle not being for sale anymore, she had her ‚Äòderri√®re‚Äô measured at a specialised shop and bought a new modern saddle. With the result that she had an awful pain after a while. She went back, could get it changed for another one with no relief. During a bike tour she went to a local bike shop as she was quite uncomfortable and just bought a cheap one, which immediately felt comfortable. In my opinion it was a rather wide saddle that I personally would never have advised. Just to say that the best way really is to experiment if you‚Äôre new to biking and be prepared to exchange your saddle once or more until you find the perfect one. And then if you buy a new bike take your saddle with you! üòú
data.author: Luuk Wndrgm

data.text: Saddles work on supporting seat bones. Weight does not determine seat bone size. If you're having trouble go get a sizing from a bike shop. Gel and padded saddles don't always work. In my experience, they rarely do.

data.text: The most important aspect of long distance bicycle riding is comfort‚Ä¶.
data.author: David O'Neill

data.text: Sella.
data.author: Patricia Seifert

data.text: The one that fits your sitting bones, because it doesn't matter if your underweight, overweight or whatever weight - you build up pressure on these two points. A soft saddle would be the worst of choices, general rule is - if you have to pad it, somethings wrong (be it the saddle itself or some parameter of the bike geometry). Get your behind (sitting bones) measured and chose your saddle accordingly. Brooks and SQLab are two very good brands.
data.author: Axel Knobbe

data.text: Depends on your riding position. Go to a better bike shop and ask for the sit bone measuring tool. Kinda like a Brannock you find in shoe stores. Measure your sit bones and they can help you. Just know that riding in a drop position is very different from more upright touring or cruising. Stay away from anything that has, "comfort" in the name. It's a marketing ploy and means nothing.
data.author: Robin Brodsky

data.text: Sofa

data.text: For a road bike ..terry century saddle. Give it 3 months. You will love it! No complaints. bought one for all my road bikes. For an upright bike??
data.author: Hope Baker

data.text: Plus size woman here currently on tour. I started my tour as a total novice and having only ever done a cumulative 20 miles on my Brooks B17 before leaving on tour. I broke it in within about 10 days of riding. It will continue to get more comfortable, just stick with it. First day hurt a lot, so I made some tweaks to the angle, second day also hurt alot lol.. but by day 4 I was pretty comfortable as a newbie.. and by day 10 I forgot all about itüòÅ
data.author: Samantha Larson
